intro: Lepidocupania myrmoctona, commonly known as the golden mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that primarily inhabits the canopy of eucalyptus forests in southeastern Australia. It relies on its host trees for water and nutrients while producing its own carbohydrates through photosynthesis. The plant has small, lance-shaped leaves and produces yellowish-green berries that are dispersed by birds. Its life cycle involves a complex relationship with its host, often leading to reduced growth and vitality in the host tree. Due to habitat loss, Lepidocupania myrmoctona is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
